Award.AwardTitle: The Formation of the First Galaxies and their Connection to the Present Day
Award.AbstractNarration:
AST-1211626
Wise

Dwarf galaxies provided the majority of the ionizing photon budget during cosmic reionization, and in fact recent observations have begun to reveal such galaxies. To understand these and planned future observations, it is necessary, and timely, to construct realistic models of high-redshift galaxies. This project will carry out cosmological adaptive mesh refinement radiation hydrodynamics simulations that focus on the formation of the first galaxies and their evolution to the present-day in varying large-scale environments. These simulations include radiative and supernova feedback, a self-consistent transition to Population II star formation, and self-regulation of star formation through radiation pressure. They will resolve molecular clouds and stellar associations, and compute radiation transport accurately using adaptive coupled ray tracing. Current observations of high-redshift galaxies and nearby dwarf galaxies will help to constrain the physical model. To make a direct connection to nearby dwarf galaxies, simulations will be embedded in a larger volume to follow dwarf galaxy evolution to the present-day and make predictions about their origin and connection to the early universe.

Involved junior researchers will gain expertise in a wide range of problems in cosmology and astrophysics, numerical algorithms, high performance computing, and software engineering. There will also be opportunities to tackle the challenging problem of visualizing results from large multi-dimensional computer simulations. The lead researcher will continue to integrate research activities into teaching in K-12 schools and other public venues, as well as through online learning environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All galaxies form from smaller building blocks that have their origin in the first billion years of the universe. This project used state-of-the-art simulations to follow the formation of the first stars and galaxies in the universe. They play a key role in the reionization of the universe that occurs when the universe was only 800 million years old. The simulations performed in this project follows the propagation of radiation from these first luminous objects into their surrounding environment. We found that nearly one-third of the photons needed for cosmic reionization originate from these smallest galaxies, which was highly unconstrained before this work. Furthermore, we established that galaxies can form in dark matter halos that were previously thought to not host any star formation. These galaxies can be as small as 5000 solar masses.  They could be the progenitors of the newly discovered ultra-faint dwarf galaxies around our Milky Way. The enhanced and dynamic physics included in our simulations allowed our group to follow the formation of these smallest galaxies in detail.

A small fraction of these building blocks are not incorporated into larger galaxies and are considered relics of the early universe. These relic galaxies provide a nearby gateway to the first epochs of galaxy formation, where clues about their initial formation can be uncovered by inspecting the elemental abundances in stars. Our simulations provide a robust connection between the first galaxies and nearby isolated dwarf galaxies in which galactic archeology can be conducted with higher precision.

These results have been disseminated in various public venues and educational forums.  They have been presented in three public talks, including a TEDx talk in April 2015 in the metro Atlanta area.  The visualizations produced from the simulations supported by this award were also incorporated in several outreach events in the visualization laboratory at Georgia Tech and in undergraduate and graduate courses at Georgia Tech. Last, the simulations conducted in this project were used in an exhibit at the Alder Planetarium in Chicago, IL and in the planetarium show, Solar Superstorms, produced by the Advanced Visualization Laboratory in the National Center for Supercomputing Applications, Thomas Lucas Productions, and Spitz Creative Media.  Solar Superstorms has been featured in various television shows and in several planetariums around the globe.
